All Classes

  • All Classes Interface Summary Class Summary Enum Summary 
    Class Description
    Account
    The Account class will be the primary working tool for organizing the transactions in terms of money coming in or money going out using the standard accounting practice of double-entry method.
    AccountCategory
    A identifiable list of accounts of the same primary type so that the Book object has a way to grab only the accounts in a certain category as organized on the balance sheet appearance of the main GUI
    AccountDialog
    This could just be called the "ledger" for each account as that's the old school (paper) model I had in mind for book keeping
    AccountType
    List of the available types of accounts
    BalanceTree
    Class to create and fill the TreeView objects for the balance sheet
    Book
    A Book is the main organizer object for this whole software application, transactions will be collected into Accounts, and the Book is a collection of accounts with measures taken to assure it is balanced, and the Book object is what will be saved/opened/worked-with by users for ongoing concerns in accounting.
    Book.AccountController
    All of the dialogs keep a reference to the current Book object, but not the primary GUI controller, so this interface assures there is a way to call the methods on the primary GUI from any dialog
    DetailsDialog
    The dialog for Book level interaction: book name (not filename to allow versioning), date opened, description, text editor for general note keeping...
    EditTransactionDialog
    The software I used previously was too easy to edit transactions, so I added a step to prevent that happening on accident so often, have to right click and then confirm changes from a separate dialog
    FundController
    The controller class for the software's main GUI
    FundMain
    The main class for this application
    HelpDialog
    Basically this reads from a text file (about.txt and UserManual.txt) to keep the info easy to edit, and sets it up to be displayed nicely on the screen for a user.
    ModifyAccountOrderDialog
    The standard practice in accounting is that accounts are listed by order of liquidity (how quickly it can be turned into cash), this dialog is for changing the order that accounts and categories of accounts appear on the balance sheet
    NewAccountCategoryDialog
    The dialog with options for creating a new category to organize accounts in on the balance sheet rather than one long list, each category will become an expandable/collapsable list of accounts on the balance sheet based primary user interface
    NewAccountDialog
    Dialog to create a new account, the traditional cornerstone of double-entry method accounting practices: some accounts increase with a debit (left column) and decrease with a credit (right column) while other accounts are the reverse and every dollar recorded is listed in both a debit and a column credit somewhere.
    NewBookDialog
    The dialog to start a new Book, which is the working file: what the user opens/edits/saves...
    NewBookType
    The available options for creating new Books, or we could just call them templates if you prefer
    RemoveAccountDialog
    Dialog to remove unwanted categories or accounts from the Book, as long as they're empty: an account must have a balance of zero and a category cannot contain any accounts in order to be deleted
    RevenueSplit
    a java class to save details for the RevenueSplitter tool, it's just a linked list of items for the tool and a string for a name to identify it with
    RevenueSplitter
    The primary control class for all of the user and machine interface components making up this tool
    RevenueSplitterItem
    Java bean style class to represent the accounts being modified, and how they're modified, by revenue splitter
    RevenueSplitterItemPane
    A set of controls for each individual item representing how money is to be distributed among various accounts
    RevenueSplitterItemPane.SplitControl
    An inner interface so that methods from the primary control object can be called safely from each independent item's controls
    Transaction
    An Transaction is the basic building block of the whole thing, it is a collection of datafields representing a single real-world monetary transaction.
